titleStmt.title: Passes granted, by the free-born people of England. To severall of the most eminent perjur'd rebels assembled in junto at Westminster. Who are now desirous to transport themselves into New-England, to Amsterdam, or Utopia. A passe for the junto in generall. To all nations of the world greeting. Know you; these traytors of the English nation; ... if we heare you hang them up, we shall not shed a teare. Subscribed, by the long abused nation of England.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

keywords.term: Great Britain -- History -- Civil War, 1642-1649 -- Early works to 1800.

revisionDesc.change: 2014-06 Apex CoVantageKeyed and coded from ProQuest page images
2014-08 Kate AllenText and markup reviewed and edited

div.p: PASSES Granted, By the Free-born People of ENGLAND.
To severall of the most eminent perjur'd Rebels Assembled in IƲNTO at WESTMINSTER.
Who are now desirous to transport themselves into New-England, to Amsterdam, or Ʋtopia.
A Passe for the Iunto in Generall.
To all Nations of the World Greeting.

lg.l: Know you; these Traytors of the English Nation;
Being compelled to forsake their Station.
When in one body were so prevalent,
They durst to call themselves a Parliament.
'Mongst us they sat seaven yeares, in which short season,
They acted seaven years, of Blood, and Treason.
Pretending to Reform; unto our terror,
They countenance' • Schismes, Factions, and all error.
Perswading us, they meant good to our King,
To make him glorious, and in every thing;
To adde unto his luster, sought his Life,
Banisht his Children, and his Loyall Wife.
While thousands of us, did in Battaile fall,
Our goods, our Lands, our Wives, our Children, all.
Subject to their Commands, but now we see
Our error, and have found their fallacie.
Th • se who escap't the Gallowes, that's their due,
We doe permit, for to reside 'mongst you.
Looke on them, as they merit; if we heare
You hang them up, we shall not shed a teare.

div.p: Subscribed, by the long abused Nation of ENGLAND.

div.head: PASSES GRANTED BY THE Free-borne People of England.
To severall the most eminent perjur'd Rebells, assembled in Iunto at Westminster. Who are now desirous to transport themselves into New England, to Amsterdam, or Ʋtopia.
A Passe for the Right Honourable Rebell, the Lord Say.
div.p: THese are to certifie, to all Nations, Kindreds, and Tongues, Iewes, Gentiles, and Christians, that the bearer hereof▪ hath showne himselfe in all things, a most obstinate Traytor against God, and a most pollitick Rebell against his King, and hath been a most zealous pretender, passing through many fiery trialls, as the thinnesse of his haire can testifie, yet it is at rotten at heart as an Apple Codled in pist straw, and as farre from piety as Loyalty; These are therefore to require you, in the name of us the Free borne People of England, to afford this Fi • e-Drake, as ample remuneration as his merits require; the People of England, leaving it to the discretion of you the Nations of the world, amongst what People soever he shall happen to reside whether you will burne him as an Heretick, or Quarter him as a Traytor, &c.

div.head: A Passe for Harry Martin, a Member of the Junto.
div.p:
THese are to give notice to all men whom it may concerne, to the end they be no • mistaken in the ma • ners, or quality of the bearer hereof, let them know, that this is Englands Arch-Traytor, even Harry▪ Martin, a slav • more salt then is the Baltick Sea, a S • tyre, or a Goa • ; a monster su •• as Affrica ne're bred, whose
damn'd projections have ruin'd and undone our glorious King, our once refulgent Church, and splendent State, who with the ayd of three more like himselfe, deviz'd a Declaration against his Soveraigne, wherein the fury indeavoured to make the People conceit, that He was guilty of his Fathers death, and was an enemy to the Common-wealth, hee kept a leash of Curti • ans, in severall quarters in and about London, consuming all the wealth hee shar'd, extorted from the miserable Communalty, on those sophisticated Beauties who in lieu of his golden courtesies, gave him the French mans itch, called Gonorhea passio, his bones fight with each other in his skin, and his sick breath is more contagious then the blew steame fat Toades evaporate, let none share in his cup, hee hath the deadly m • lady of France; these are therefore to advertise all to who •
〈◊〉
Salama • der shall repaire, to take strict notice of the premis 〈…〉 and to use him according to his wor • h, &c.

div.head: Sir HENRY VANE, or Vaine his Passe.
div.p:
TO all Nations, to whom this Certificate shall come greeting, know you that wee the Free-borne people of England, have licenced this vaine fellow the bearer hereof, to take his progresse through the world, provided that it doe not happen to him, according to Caines feare, that whosoever meeteth him kill him. Know therefore, that the bearer hereof is one, then whom, the Scicilians found no greater Torment, the emblem of Ingratitude, one whom his King once lookt upon with a gracious eye and exalted to dignity, and under whom hee got much wealth, by forgerie, perjury, and cunning. And yet this devill in recompence of his Soveraignes love, hath been on all occasions the first in speaking or acting against him; hee is a meer Weathercock, not so much as a luke-warme Christian, but a very
politick Atheist; These are therefore to require you on his behalfe (if it be so that you are in love with your owne destruction) quietly to permit and suffer him to dwel amongst you, and to spend that wealth in quiet, which he hath illegally and devillishly heaped together, out of the Plundered substance of us the Free-borne people of England; or otherwise, if you be perswaded of a truth of our observation, to hang him up as a perfidious Traytor, &c.

div.head: A Passe for the most pollitick Lord HERBERT, Earle of Pembroke.
div.p: WEe the Freeborne people of England, as having experience of this worthy Earle and his wisdome, he now being desirous to travaile in forraigne Countries, the more to take himselfe off from serious studies, the prying into which hath dried him up almost to a Skelleton; so that his face is become the perfect resemblance of an Hatchet, doe with all our soules, not unmindfull of his great merit, give unto him this our Passe.

Know you then that the bearer hereof, is that dam▪ mee Earl, called the Earl of Pembroke, who hath sate this 7 yeares amongst other of his Fraternitie, who call themselves a Parliament, in the shape of this figure—O—, during which time, though he had not wit enough to bee a Statesman; yet he had wickednesse sufficient to be a Rebell, and to be as forward as the rest in Voting against the King, and his loyall Subjects; he had so much sense as on all occasions to runne with the Wind, turne with the Tide, and vary with the Camelion; when the Presbyters were prevalent, he swore God dam-him, hee was for Ruling Elders, and Provinciall Assemblies; when the Independents got into the saddle, he swore wounds and blood, Independency was the best
and though the foole had never so much learning as to read a Chapter in the Bible▪ nor ever attained to so much knowledge, as to conster a lesson out of Cato; yet he had the impudence and arrogance as to except the Ʋice-Chancelours place of Oxford, the well-spring of Learning, and the seat of the Muses; where to shew that his Ideotishp had arived to the highest perfection of folly, he turned out all the able Pillars, and Moderators of that University, and placed in their stead, a sort of Sniveling Ignorant Factionists, to the ruine of that renowned Academie; These are therefore to desire you not to be mistaken in the man, whose manners we ha • e in part discovered, but to use him with such honour as he deserves, &c.

div.head: Serjant Wild his Passe.
div.p: BE it knowne unto all Nations, wheresoever the bearer h • r of shal come, that this Passe is granted by us the Free borne People of England, with much reluctancie, we rather having desired to have taken this Wild and cruell Boare in our toiles, and to have offered him up in sacrifice to Astera, but that it might not be accomp • ished, we have afforded him this Certificate under our hands and Seales.

Know then that this bearer, is one of the most perfidious, treacherous, bloody, implacable Trayto •• , that ever beheld the Sunne; this is the envious Horse-leach that suckt the blood of that Loyall Martyr, Captaine BV • LEIGH, who was hangd, drawn and quartered as a Traytor, for attempting to rescue his Soveraigne Lord and King, out of Prison, where he was shut up in more privacie then an Anchorite, and used more rigorously, then a Patricide, dooming him to die contrary to the expresse Law of the Land, and passing his sentence with mocks and scornes, and that you may be the
better informed of the worth of this bearer, take notice that this is the hell-hound, whom the Iunto at Westminster made their chiefe Agent on all occasions, to prosecute to the death, all such Loyall Subjects who either worshiped God, in his true Religion or gave honour to their Prince, according to their duty; this is that Caniball, whom the Traytors at Westminster, allot nothing for food but humane flesh, who lately was sent downe to Canterbury, and by their counterfeit Seale authorized to trie for their lives; divers honest men of the City of Canterbury (that assembled them selves together, more in merriment, then for any designe) by a Commissioner of Oyer and Terminer, where with strong arguments, not taken from Law, but wrested, he indeavoured to bereave those innocent men of their lives, had not the Iury been indewed with more conscience then this Iew and so brought in their Verdict as Ignoramus, these are therefote to • e • uire you to yeild him as much accommodation, as his deserts require, &c.

div.head: The High and Mighty, King Oliver, his Passe.
div.p: ALthough it be without president, that Subjects should give a Passe to their King, yet it happens to be so with us now, and with our King of clouts; and therefore to all Nations, kindr • ds, and tongues greeting.

These are to certifie you, that this swabberd, this Copper-nose cut-throat, alias Nol Crumwell, is one of the most desperate and seditious, incorrigible and bloody Traytors, • hat ever survived, by whose single violence, we have been exposed to all miseries and calamities, so great and so grievous, that never any Nation, tasted of the like; this trim Prodegia, whose heart deserves to be splin • erd with needles, and whose▪ meat ought to be str • wed ore with Serpents
teeth, hath been the ring-leader of all the rout at Westminster, the whole rable hearkning to his pernicious advice, with as much superstitious zeale, as ever the Heathens of old to their Oracles; he had once hoped to have reduced all things to a parity, but his Levellers lost their aime, and were whipt running, and Nol, being to great a Fly to be caught in that Cobweb, scapt Scot-free; and that you may be the more induced, to accommodate this Meteor, with all love and respect; take notice, that the glazing, furbushing, and quality of his Nose is such, that if you hang him up on a Gibbet, in some te • ebrous place, where many wayes meet, and Travailers may easily wander out of the way, the refulgencie of his Nose, will give more light then a Beacon, and which will be more advantagious; no Beare, Wolfe, or any other ravenous, or truculent beast, will dare to come within twenty miles of him, and that you may not faile to use him courteously as aforesaid; take notice that he is a perjur'd Villaine, who once made Protestation, before the worlds eye, and the eyes of men, that he would doe his utmost to restore his King to his Just Power and Greatnesse, as before he and his Rebellious complices, had devested him, and stripped him of all, and yet afterwards broke his faith, and persecuted him with deadly spight, and indeavouring by all wayes and meanes, to take his Life, and in his fall to roote out Monarchicall Government; these are therefore to desire you to use this Regicide, carefully.

closer.signed: Subscribed by us, the Free-borne (yet inslaved People of England) now upon the point to break our yoake, redeeme our King, to regaine our Church, and to recover our lost Lawes.

lg.head: (To the Rebells.)
lg.l: Your Passes are all made▪ n • w when you please,
You ma • in winged v • ssels, plow the Seat.

Hast, hast for
• ericho th • se walls upreare;
For we are weary, of your working here.
